utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Juan Williams along with Katie Pavlich, Jesse Watters, Kennedy, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City. This is “The Five.” Bernie Sanders out on the campaign trail today. He made an official push for his socialist agenda. Here's the proposals he is planning.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Every American, regardless of his or her income, is entitled to the right to a decent job that pays a living wage. The right to quality healthcare. The right to a complete education. The right to affordable housing. The right to a clean environment and the right to a secure retirement. Democratic socialism means to me requiring and achieving political and economic freedom in every community. The only way we achieve these goals is through a political revolution.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Sanders also slammed President Trump accusing him of being a socialist but one for the wealthy.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: While President Trump and his fellow oligarchs attack us for our support of Democratic socialism, they don't really oppose all forms of socialism. They may hate Democratic socialism because it benefits working people but they absolutely love corporate socialism that enriches Trump and other billionaires.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, a new Harris poll showing that 55 percent of women between the ages of 18 and 54 actually support pure socialism. So, Greg, I'm coming to you first --

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because I want to hear your response, your thoughts on --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- that Sanders says Trump is a socialist for the rich.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know, crazy, huh? He is preaching revolution during the largest period of economic expansion in recent history. And for the first time there is like no war in the western hemisphere and he is pushing an ideology, ironically that crushes economic expansion and inevitably results in violence and war. Because when people want to achieve, you have to -- if you want an equality of outcomes you have to crush them. I mean, he is making a case for socialism during the greatest economic time in history. That's like going to a healthy village in the middle ages and say, and extolling the virtues of the plague. It is absolute -- it makes no sense. So, it's wrong. It's actually morally wrong.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because people are living longer, healthier lives and he is preaching a belief system that starves people to death. It's wrong.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Katie, though, what I was getting at with Greg was, he is saying Trump is for socialism for the rich while Sanders says he is for socialism for working families. Let me just give you an example. He, Sanders says lower healthcare costs, lower the cost of education. Let's make reasonable housing prices. I think most Americans would say yes, that's a good idea.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I think that Bernie Sanders maybe should sell two of his three homes before he starts preaching about rich people being the enemy. Notice how he caps the number for his estate tax at $3.5 million where he is worth about $1.5 million. Interesting. He has changed his stump speech from millionaires and billionaires to just billionaires. But he is preaching something -- you know, he is saying he wants to re-do the new deal. That FDR had a good vision for the country. But if you actually look at the results for that for the past 50 years, we spent $21 trillion, which was supposed to bring people out of poverty. It has not. But capitalism has. Capitalism has not only brought people out of poverty in America but all over the world throughout the past half a century. And that is what we should be focused on. Not taking from others and saying that every single thing is a right. And one more thing. He keeps saying that this isn't about real socialism. He doesn't want to take over every kind of industry. In order to provide economic rights and healthcare rights and every right that he listed in his speech, you have to take over industries and force them to provide it because that's the only way that you can deliver on those promises.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Huh, I didn't think he was talking about take over industries but that's what you --

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX BUSINESS HOST
utterances.utterance: you have to. He talked about since the '70s.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, that was way back.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes. But in the '70s when he was also extolling the virtues of the Soviet Union where he continually honeymooned. He was also talking about taking over not only healthcare but entire sectors like banking. And he really hasn't changed that much. The thing about Bernie Sanders you try to press him he is actually very good at weaseling out of answering some of these critical questions. Define socialism, because they are constantly changing the term and the definition. And he says, well, it's Democratic socialism. So, there is a qualification there. But that's still socialism and Katie is absolutely right. It is a taking. It is a government taking and the idea that the government owes me this. The government can't just provide it. The government has to take it from somewhere else. And I think people are going to be shocked when they realize they're the ones who are being taken from.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And their taxes are going to double just to pay for healthcare and I disagree with him. I don't think all of these things are a right that the government owes you and if you look at education, if you look at healthcare, if you look at housing, just those three areas where the government is so vastly involved, that's where these programs are upside down, that's where people are hurting the most. And that's where lower income people get absolutely hosed because there is too much government interference.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, so this is, you know, let's play hard ball and real politics. Because we have a Quinnipiac poll but even the president's own pollster, Tony Fabrizio saying "I think six Democrats right now beat Trump head-to-head nationally including Bernie Sanders." What do you make of this?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't believe those polls. I think they had Reagan losing in a landslide in '84 to Mondale. And he was the one that won in a landslide.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't remember that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, we're way, way out from what's really going to happen. To your point about Trump being a corporate socialist. Trump wasn't the one that bailed out the big banks. Trump wasn't the one that threw $500 million at Solyndra. Trump is actually jawboning a lot of these big corporations to keep production here instead of offshoring it overseas. He is jawboning like Lockheed Martin to keep the price down on the jets. Wall Street donated more to Hillary than they did to Donald Trump. He is constantly going after billionaires like Bezos and what's his name George Soros? And if you look income inequality has actually shrunk under President Trump whereas under Barack Obama it expanded.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, I don't know about that. But anyway --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But let me just ask -- I just trust you. But let me just say what about the tax cut? I think what Bernie is saying actually we do take from people. We take from the working-class people in this country who are having tougher time and we give it to the rich and say, it will be trickle down if the rich do better than everyone.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We didn't give it to the rich it was their money to begin with. And I've always said I thought the tax cuts should have been much bigger for individual and family taxpayers. But the companies needed a break, too. Because they were unfairly targeted compared to the rest of the west.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The fact is, the majority of the country, the majority of the middle class got a tax cut.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like 85 percent.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The New York Times even admitted that they did. So, to say that the middle class didn't get one is not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The other thing too, is you keep saying we need to have affordable this and affordable that. What makes things affordable? Competition. What's missing in socialism? Competition. What raises prices if you go to any socialist country and you can't find a loaf of bread and if you find one it's $47.50. Competition.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, it's like the only way. Sanders doesn't like competition. That's why he has never had a real job.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Don't you remember that he, you know, this curmudgeon went into -- he went into bodega and complained that there were too many choices for deodorant?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: As though choice were somehow --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a good thing.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- a foul concept? And it's like, that's great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Just pick one.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: When the market is providing that and you can pick exactly what you want, I think that's a sign of success. And to say your point, Juan, I think Bernie Sanders could have done very well in 2008. And that was the time to run on this agenda. And because, you know, you remember that was the beginning of the Great Recession.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And he would have had an easier time selling some of these programs because if you are selling a massive too big to fail multiple trillion-dollar stimulus package, then that's the time you tell people and we are going to pay for housing, and we are going to pay for education.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I don't think he's -- you guys talk about takeover of government or takeover of industry. I think he's talking about Democrat --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because he talks about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, hold on.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: What did he say about insurance companies though?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hold on. Hold on.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: What did he say about insurance companies?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. What he is saying is Democratic socialism which is basically safety net which is why I think is popular.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Medicare for all takes everybody health insurance that we all like from our companies that we work for --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- and they give it over to the government and the government runs healthcare. That's a government takeover. And I don't think the government can even handle the small things? Do you want to put them in charge of healthcare?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We are saying it because Bernie Sanders said it. That's what the facts are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. First it was Nancy Pelosi. Now a 2020 candidate looking for Trump to be behind bars. The details on THE FIVE next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: First it was Nancy Pelosi calling for President Trump to be locked up. Now it's 2020 hopeful Kamala Harris who wants to see the president behind bars. She is shining a light on what her presidential agenda would look like if she were to win the White House. Starting with prosecuting Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF., PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: Everyone should be held accountable. And the president is not above the law.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT DETROW, CO-HOST, NPR POLITICS PODCAST
utterances.utterance: Even if it meant a former president going on trial serving jail time?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: Well, the facts and the evidence will take the process where it leads. But I have read the Mueller report. I do believe that we should believe Bob Mueller when he tells us essentially that the only reason that an indictment was not returned is because of a memo in the Department of Justice that suggests you cannot indict a sitting president. But I have seen prosecution of cases on much less evidence.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That argument is getting quite old. The president early today slamming Democrats and their relentless attempts to rehash the Mueller report.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: The Democrats are trying to do because they know they are going to lose the election so they are going to give this is a shot. Every day they are going more and more after, after. We have people that are totally out of control. The Mueller report spoke. They were very disappointed it said no collusion and no collusion and no obstruction and no nothing. So now they are trying to do a do-over or a re-do and we're not doing that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And apparently, there is now a whole day devoted to pushing for Trump's impeachment. This Saturday over 100 events are planned across the country in what is being called an impeach Trump day of action. Greg, are you going to be out on the streets?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know it. I will wear my special impeachment outfit which is nothing at all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You'll wear that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, before there were these dating apps, you actually had to go to a bar to meet people. It was really weird. You have to work up the gumption to say hello. That's what candidates are like right now. They are the desperate guy at the bar who will say anything to get your number. And it's just to get some kind of media spotlight. And they are not trying to appeal to America. Because America doesn't care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They are looking for attention.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are looking for attention. So, they are chasing the extreme voices on Twitter and the media who coincidentally share those extreme voices. And they are being tricked into thinking there is no lane for moderates. Like everybody has to go this way and actually, America actually likes the moderate. You don't have to be a rabid flame thrower. I don't believe her for a second. But it's interesting that she has to do this because she is not taking off. And I thought that that she would have taken off. I know it's early but I would have expected more from Kamala or Kamala.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kamala.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Kamala.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think there is a long way to go. And maybe --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kamala. I'm sorry. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe, Greg, maybe some of these people that voted in the Democratic primaries they want Donald Trump prosecuted when he leaves office. Maybe she is just appealing to them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, it's like 70 percent of Democrats want to impeach.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, she went even further and said wants him behind bars after he leaves office.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no, no, no. I mean, the difference here is she --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a big difference, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She read the report, the Mueller report. This is what Mueller said. Nobody -- I don't know how many people read the report but she read the report.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We all did, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because what it said --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm tired of being told I didn't read it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because she is not picking on him --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But you didn't read it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. I'm tired of people telling me that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But wait a minute, wait a minute. You got to slam me better than that. You just give into Jesse? Hey, wait a minute. OK. But anyway, the idea is that if you read the Mueller report he makes the case that this guy obstructed justice.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And then he says but the DOJ policy is and so maybe some other process, notably the Congress and impeachment can take place.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Do you know who else is a prosecutor in addition to Kamala? Robert Mueller. And he was the ultimate prosecutor. And he is the guy that ran the show. The fact is that, if he had a crime, he could prosecute he could have said even though we cannot indict --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- the president or charge him with a crime while he is in office, these are the crimes that we found. Here's the evidence to back it up. He didn't do any of those things. And it is highly alarming that the woman who wants to be president of the United States is openly saying she will use the Department of Justice again like Barack Obama did as a political weapon to go after a political opponent when he is out of office.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMNS
utterances.utterance: Mike Flynn standing up there?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why can't she do it -- why can't she can do it against any citizen if she can do it to anybody?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, Mike Flynn is -- Mike Flynn is going to jail. He was the one standing on the stage --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK. But Donald Trump is not going to jail because there is no evidence to put him in jail.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- to the Republican convention saying lock her up, lock her up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, first, the Democrats spy on Trump and then they want to throw him behind bars when he leaves office.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I mean, I don't understand where these Democrats are coming from who want this job. They want to make it -- they want it super easy to remove the president, yet they want to be president and, therefore, they are leaving a trail for how they can be easily removed.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But the Republicans will never do anything like that.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: So, you know, and a lot of people are --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know they won't.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- a lot of people are saying this. It's like Biden is the frontrunner now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And then right after Biden it's Bernie, Elizabeth Warren, and Mayor Pete. And then Kamala is a few percentage points after them. And they are saying Kamala, you know, she will be a natural V.P. choice. I think with some of her comments she is actually running for A.A. That's what it sounds like.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And you know, that's -- she is definitely --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If she is not V.P. she could be A.G. I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I just bring in some breaking news? I mean, because there is a reality in terms of what's going on. We had Donald Trump, Jr. back before Senate intelligence, right, for several hours. And now we hear that Hope Hicks, whose communications director at Fox --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- that she is going to testify.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you still with the witch-hunt?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm with the witch hunt.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But, Juan --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you still on the collusion thing?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Juan, do you know what would have been nice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: If we weren't left in this expanded gray area which is what the Mueller report gave us. And I really do wish that he would have picked a side. And I wish he would have pressed the issue.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICHZ
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And if the president had done something so bad that was chargeable, if it were a civilian, then he should have put that in there. And he also he should have tried to charge him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Imagine how I feel, Kennedy? I agree with you, Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, even Bill Barr said when he found out they weren't going to charge he said, are you kidding me? What are you doing here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why are we all talking about this? Because the economy is doing great, unemployment is great.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Animals are great.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Animals are great. So, we got to talk about the collusion thing forever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Hard core partisan hack Rachel Maddow tapped to moderate an upcoming 2020 Democrat debate. Greg breaks it down next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, while the media spent Tuesdays finding new ways to say how Biden will eviscerate Trump or they miss actual news. The host of the first debate include Rachel Maddow. On the bright side it could have been John Brennan and Joy Behar. Instead, we get the duchess of smirk. Talking about taking the moderate out of the moderator. Rachel is to the left of Marx, and I don't mean the brothers or Richard. Now she is totally capable but she is also totally biased. Her livelihood depends on it. And after she spent two years talking a fantasy that painted the president as a Russian stooge. Do you think the Dems would think twice about letting her near the stage? In case you forgot, here's some of her best work.

utterances.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, HOST, MSNBC
utterances.utterance: This guy Kilimnik keeps turning up again and again. Konstantin Kilimnik, Konstantin Kilimnik, and Konstantin Kilimnik. Konstantin Kilimnik he is still Russian military intelligence. Kilimnik, a short man who goes by "Kostya" -- this guy Konstantin Kilimnik. Aluminum smelters, this is sleeping at his smelters. Sabotage in his smelters came to his smelters. Alex van der Zwaan? Alex van der Zwaan. Alex van der Zwaan chromium number 24. Chromium plant in Kazakhstan. Chromium plant in Kazakhstan. Next time you see something chrome plated take a deep breath, cough it out and think of the Trump Soho. Big story, tick, tick, tick, boom. Started ticking again, tick, tick, tick, tick. Four hours later. Boom, boom. You are stressing me out. He starts tick, tick, ticking again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now the obvious point is, what if Fox News had pulled this stunt and picked a highly opinionated moderator. Sadly, Diamond and Silk were busy. But we assumed our media pals would get wind of it but strange that's not the case here. It's odd how little a ripple this made in the media pond. Instead they just push absurd hallucinations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: A lot of people are talking about now is that, if he loses, Trump, he won't go. I absolutely think he will not leave.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How deranged do you have to be not just to believe that but to actually say it out loud. The derangement blinds you so much that you forget it's your side trying to undo an election. It's not Trump resisting the vote of the voters but the left concocting ways to seize power that doesn't require elections. But I get it. It's been a rough two years for the media. The country is doing great and that's bad if your industry is built on bad news. The only thing they have going for them an active imagination. Too bad the public has learned to ignore it. All right, Katie, it's a -- they knew they could make this brazen choice because they knew no one would call him on it, right?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, the idea that they will pick Rachel Maddow but won't do a Fox News debate with moderators who are in the news business really is astounding to me. Rachel Maddow is basically a conspiracy theorist if we look back at all the Russia coverage that she did that she claimed was factual. Let's question what she actually got right, very, very little of it. She sat there when Lawrence O'Donnell who is on after her said that maybe President Trump responded to Syria and that the Syrians launched a chemical weapons attack to distract away from the Russia issue. I mean, that's a pretty serious conspiratorial charge to make. And this is all about the double standard, right? Conservative media, conservatives are never allowed to ask the questions. Whenever they get a question at the White House press briefing or during a press conference they are berated by the press as not real journalists capable of asking questions. But Rachel Maddow can moderate a debate. It's a double standard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The thing is, you know -- yes. And, Juan, you know, at Fox we have our commentators and we have -- but we label everything. When you go to the Fox News fridge, you know what you are getting, do you know what I mean? You have your straight vodka and then have you your vodka and soda.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: What are you, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know what I am. I'm kumquat juice.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, how that pop into your head.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I have no idea.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You are a sick man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You got to squeeze a lot of kumquats to get juice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's kind of tart. I would say generally, you know, we've had people who have opinions as debate moderators. But I think this is sort of egregious, and I'll tell you why. I think we try to abide here at Fox that there is a line between people who are opinion --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- and people who are news. Some people criticize. But look, I've seen this line, and I think the public is best served when it's not blurred. I've seen it here. I have seen it at the Washington Post. At the Washington Post I was both reporter and an editorial writer. And when I was a reporter the editorial people didn't tell me what to do. And when I was an editorial writer I never even talked to the journalists.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, it seems to me as someone who has done a debate for Fox, it would -- I can't believe that MSNBC is doing this and I think to pick up on what you were saying, I'm surprised that the Democratic Party isn't saying hey, we don't like it because it then opens the door to conservatives doing the same thing down the line.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And that opens the door for Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's probably --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what Hannity said by the way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true. Diamond and Silk and Watters. There you go.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: My God --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's probably in contract though to moderate these debates and NBC didn't want to cause any problems with their biggest political star. They have enough problems. They are getting sued for a quarter of a billion dollars by the Covington boys. They spiked that Weinstein expose. You know, things didn't work out with Megyn Kelly. It didn't work out with Brian Williams, it didn't work out with Matt Lauer so there is a lot of problems over there. They don't need this. They have a lot invested in Rachel but her brand has suffered because she lied for two years. And so, they need to realign her brand with the NBC News division to resuscitate her credibility now because even the New York Times reporters aren't allowed on her show because she's too fringe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But what do you make all of this Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Well, I look at this and I think, if I'm an independent or Democrat voter and I'm looking at this field, I wouldn't hear from them. And I want to hear how they take each other on, how they present their ideas and if they can do something other than attack the President, which Rachel Maddow can't do that. And so the biggest worry for voters like that if she's going to insert herself too much into the debates, when really these stages both of them are going to be incredibly crowded, and you have to be very precise and how you extract information and the questions you ask, so the candidates have to think. And Lord knows that - I don't know that she's capable of asking a really tough follow-up question. And you sold Charlemagne and Elizabeth Warren, it takes one follow-up question to completely trip up a candidate, and I think it's really important when you've got such a crowded field.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And they're not going to - and she's not going to ask questions that the - that will pull anybody to the middle. It'll just be how liberal can you get or less--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Which candidates does she like best, is she going to go easier on them, and that's also a disservice to people watching.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I actually don't mind her asking the questions, I mind that there's a double standard about who gets to ask the questions. I think that people are capable of reporting and also having opinions, but this idea that only the Left is allowed and the Far-Left is allowed to ask the questions legitimately, that's where it gets ridiculous. Like if Rachel Maddow is capable of asking questions, so is Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is she going to ask Liz Warren about her fake Indian heritage?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Probably not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I probably don't think so. And she's had Liz Warren on her show about three times, I think, more than any other Democrat Presidential candidate. She's been on Rachel Maddow Show a lot, so it's pretty clear you know there's a rooting interest there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is an outrage. By the way, I'll - Bill Maher is a smart guy. How can you believe that a President would say I'm not leaving? I mean, that is like the most insidious thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Greg, didn't Trump say in the course of the last leg of 2016 that he would - he's not going to necessarily abide by the results?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and it was Hillary that didn't abide by the results.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She still thinks she--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: This is way Bill Maher has lost it. He used to be funny. He used to be relevant, but he's acting as though the President has already been defeated. We haven't had the election yet and we have a lot of run-up between now and then, so stop acting like he's barricaded himself inside the Oval Office with a water pistol and Michael Cohen's carcass.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. U.S. women's national soccer team being attacked for trouncing Thailand in their World Cup opener, the controversy next.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, if you're sick of winning don't rewatch the U.S. women's national soccer team's first game in the World Cup yesterday. The U.S. powerhouse team crushing Thailand 13 to 0, critics quick to pounce on the win, saying the team running up the score and excessively celebrating their goals was "Disrespectful and disgraceful". But Head Coach Jill Ellis is defending her team.

utterances.speaker: JILL ELLIS, U.S. WOMEN'S NATIONAL SOCCER COACH
utterances.utterance: This is a World Championship so every team that's here has been fantastic to get to this point. And I think that to be respectful to opponents is to play hard against opponents, and it is as Sir Alex said, it's a tournament where gold differential is a criteria.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why do you hate the score run-up from yesterday?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We watched it happening--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, it's an interesting fun fact. They scored more goals in one game than a typical men's team scores in an entire season. Did you know that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: As I made it up. This is also what shut up about politics moment. I actually don't mind sports - I just hate it when politics and Megan Rapinoe, as you know, is somebody that - I guess, I don't know, kind of like - she was part of the whole kneeling and stuff. And whenever - I just keep that away. But I will tell you this, what's worse than all of this, is pretending you know why they scored so many goals, because it has to do with - what? What does that have to do with?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Differential.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Differential.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So yesterday Dana was sitting here - Dana was sitting here and she didn't know why they scored all those goals. So she asked Allison (ph), our Floor Director, why do they score all those goals? And you said, "Oh, it's because of the different--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Differential.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Differential. And then Dana went on Twitter and there was somebody like, "Why they are scoring" - she goes, it's because of the differential. And then she had a little emoji of something like this. And it's like, you just stole that information from our Floor Director--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She is not even here to defend her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know - I didn't know she was off today. I wrote three pages of notes condemning Dana's behavior.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can use those another time.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: We may all get trophies when were five years old, but the World Cup, only one team gets the trophy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You're a competitor, you're an athlete, how do you feel about them running up the score?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, I also love the United States of America and I think the U.S. Women's National Team is phenomenal and it just goes to show when they celebrate every goal, how much they want this, and how important it is to them and how they work for this their entire lives and their careers. From the time they start playing in early adolescence or childhood, all the way through college, and if they're lucky they get on successive World Cup teams. Alex Morgan had five goals yesterday and three assists. They did so beautifully and it means something to them. And for them to celebrate as Americans, we should be high-fiving along with them. And of course I feel bad for the Thai women's team. This is their first time in World Cup play. And yet it feels horrible to get shutout. It always does. But I also thought that the U.S. woman were very gracious to their competitors after the game.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I agree with the coach, I mean, this is the big leagues.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: This is you got a win and you got to win hard and you got to win early and I actually don't feel so bad. It'll mean make the Thai team better--

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: --and better team--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Because now they'll not want to get shut out again, so they'll go back and practice and be a better team.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And they still have two more games to play at least.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's just a big deal because usually games are like won nothing, that's why people care about this. It was just an eyebrow raising event. In tennis if someone beats you 6-Love, 6-Love, two sets in girls tennis, no one cares. If someone wins--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Why don't you care about girls tennis, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sexist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I defended Serena Williams on this show dammit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can't keep bringing out that card.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I will play if I had to Gutfeld. And in football, if you're up 54- 12 and you just run the ball. You don't throw it deep, so there's ways to do it. I understand about excessive celebration, maybe on the 11th or the 12th goal--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know, maybe you don't have to slide around and do a dance, I get that. But it's like black flipping when you're up 13 nothing in baseball, you don't need that. But you know what, let them have their win and I'm proud of them.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: So, Juan, there have been questions from some of the teammates asking, "Would you tell a men's soccer team not to celebrate too hard?"

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you would. I mean. I think that you know like we have the NBA playoffs going on right now and you can see that at some games, in fact, at the end, if one team is up the other team would if dribble the ball out. Just - I mean, it's not like you're going to and just run up the score for no reason. There is a real legitimate reason why the U.S. women's team did this, as Greg was pointing out, because of goal differential. Down the line, if there's any kind of tie, the U.S. wants to move ahead. I can understand that. The question in my mind was, is there a mercy rule? Is there some way that people could act in way--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They should have a mercy rule on this show, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, then you would be out.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You know what, the men's team had the mercy rule when they didn't show up in the World Cup. But the mercy didn't make the World Cup last--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You mean our team - but I mean, no - I mean, let's not be critical.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: So let the women celebrate and if they are that fantastic than they can celebrate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
